_pi_cruise_control¶

Simulation and Control of a cruise ?

pynumdiff.utils._pi_cruise_control.desired_velocity(n, factor)¶

Wrapper for defining the desired velocity as a matrix with size [1, M], where M is the number of time points to simulate See function “run” for how this function gets used.

Parameters

  • n (int) – number of time points to simulate

  • factor (float) – factor that determines the magnitude of the desired velocity

Returns

desired velocity as function of time, a [1,M] matrix, M is the number of time points to simulate

Return type

np.matrix

pynumdiff.utils._pi_cruise_control.effective_wheel_radius(v=20)¶

Allow effective wheel radius to be a function of velocity.

Parameters

v – ignored for now

Returns

effective wheel radius, constant for now

Return type

float

pynumdiff.utils._pi_cruise_control.hills(iterations, dt, factor)¶

Wrapper for creating a hill profile for the car to drive over that has an appropriate length and magnitude

Parameters

  • iterations (int) – number of time points to simulate

  • dt (float) – timestep of simulation in seconds

  • factor (int) – determines magnitude of the hills

Returns

hills, the output of the triangle function, a [1,M] matrix where M is the number of time points simulated

Return type

np.matrix

pynumdiff.utils._pi_cruise_control.run(timeseries_length=4, dt=0.01)¶

Simulate proportional integral control of a car attempting to maintain constant velocity while going up and down hills. This function is used for testing differentiation methods.

See Astrom and Murray 2008 Chapter 3.

Parameters

  • timeseries_length (float) – number of seconds to simulate

  • dt (float) – timestep in seconds

Returns

a tuple consisting of arrays of size [N, M], where M is the number of time steps.: - state_vals: state of the car, i.e. position and velocity as a function of time - disturbances: disturbances, ie. hills, that the car is subjected to - controls: control inputs applied by the car

Return type

tuple -> (np.array, np.array, np.array)

pynumdiff.utils._pi_cruise_control.step_forward(state_vals, disturbances, desired_v, dt)¶

One-step Euler integrator that takes the current state, disturbances, and desired velocity and calculates the subsequent state.

Parameters

  • state_vals (np.matrix) – current state [position, velocity, road_angle]

  • disturbances (np.matrix) – current hill angle

  • desired_velocity (np.matrix) – current desired velocity

  • dt (float) – time step (seconds)

Returns

a tuple consisting of: - new_state: new state - u: control inputs

Return type

tuple -> (np.matrix, np.matrix)

pynumdiff.utils._pi_cruise_control.torque(omega)¶

Convert throttle input to Torque. See Astrom and Murray 2008 Chapter 3.

Parameters

omega (float) – throttle

Returns

motor torque

Return type

float

pynumdiff.utils._pi_cruise_control.triangle(iterations, dt)¶

Create sawtooth pattern of hills for the car to drive over.

Parameters

  • iterations (int) – number of time points in time series

  • dt (float) – time step in seconds

Returns

time series of hills (angle of road as a function of time)

Return type

np.matrix
